Triggering Event:
Scenario:

She returned home from work to an empty house, her husband still at his business trip. The silence was deafening. She heated up leftovers for dinner alone, the microwave's hum filling the void briefly before plunging her back into solitude. As she ate, she noticed a group text message notification on her phone - friends planning a weekend hike, not including her. She paused, her reflection in the window staring back at her, lonely amidst the flickering lights of the city.

Triggering Event: He found the empty wine glass in his girlfriend's car, still damp with last night's lipstick stains.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, I'm so angry! She doesn't even care about me anymore. It's always like this—she just leaves me behind every time she goes out. And it’s never just one time; it happens all the time. She must be doing something with someone else, and she doesn’t even try to hide it. I know everything that's going on because she always leaves the evidence right there. I can see her drinking alone at the bar, and she’s probably cheating on me. We were supposed to go on vacation together, but she just cancelled and went somewhere else with him. I swear, she loves him more than she loves me. This is always happening, and it’s not just once or twice—it keeps happening over and over again."

Triggering Event: A nurse, early 20s, divorced, worries constantly about her elderly mother's health. One evening, she receives a call from the neighbor: "Your mom fell and I can't wake her up."
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, this is terrible. She was always worried about her mom falling. They're going to have to take her to the hospital now. And it's probably broken something. My mom doesn't handle pain well. This is so bad. The neighbor said she couldn't wake her up. That means she has serious injuries. I'm already imagining all the complications, how she'll need surgery and rehabilitation. We might lose our home because my mom needs full time care. How are we going to afford it? What if they don't let her live at home anymore? Or worse, what if she dies? I just know she won't recover, and I'm so scared for my dad. He's already stressed with work. This is too much. It's like the universe is conspiring against us. I feel sick. I hope my mom wakes up soon, but I know it won't be okay.

Triggering Event: 22-year-old male software engineer, married, sits alone in his dimly lit apartment late at night, coding for work, when he hears a faint creaking from the bedroom. He hesitates, fingers trembling over the keyboard, before deciding to investigate, his fear growing with each careful step towards the darkened room.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

In the quiet of her tiny apartment, she sat alone at the kitchen table, her eyes burning with unshed tears as she stared at the photograph clutched between trembling fingers. A harsh knock at the door startled her, and she quickly wiped her cheeks before opening it to reveal a familiar face - her mentor from the restaurant where she'd worked tirelessly for years. He held out an envelope towards her, his expression somber. "I'm sorry, kid," he said, "but we've had to let you go."
Generated Assessment: She was devastated by the news, but instead of focusing on the facts, she jumped to conclusions about why she was being fired. She thought maybe her boss didn't like her, that she wasn't good enough, or perhaps there was something wrong with her appearance.

Triggering Event: He arrives home, greeted by an unusual silence. No cheerful hello from his wife, no clatter of pots from the kitchen. Instead, he finds her in the living room, surrounded by open boxes, holding a framed photo - their wedding picture. She looks up at him, her eyes cold, and says, "I found your emails."
